data.title: 45 Best Karaoke Songs and Sing
data.meta_description: What is the best karaoke song of all time? Well, leave that to us. Here are the best tunes and sing-a-longs ever.
data.text:
You might have the most impressive pipes in the whole of your city. You might sound like a strangled cat when you sing, especially after a few drinks. But whatever your range and ability, you will take to the stage for one of these karaoke songs. And it will be brilliant.

Choosing the right song is crucial. If you can't sing in tune, perhaps opt for a rap. If you want to show off that high range, potentially opt for a bit of Whitney. In our list of the best karaoke songs ever, we've got everyone from Madonna to Lizzo, and from Toto to Frank Sinatra. Take a shot and warm up those vocal chords, people. These are the best karaoke songs ever.

Contributors: Nick Levine, Adam Feldman, Matthew Singer, Ella Doyle, Amy Houghton and Ed Cunningham.

RECOMMENDED:

ğŸ¶The best â€™80s songs

ğŸ¶ The best â€™90s songs

ğŸ‰ The best party songs ever made

ğŸ¸ The best classic rock songs

ğŸ•º The best pop songs of all time

1. â€˜Like a Prayerâ€™ by Madonna

This sacreligious banger by the queen of pop herself pulls in captivated listeners from the word go. â€˜Life is a mystery, everyone must stand aloneâ€™, you croon, your voice a stream of light piercing through the darkest night. Heads turn, crowds gather, then BOOM: off pops that unignorable beat as the â€˜80s anthemâ€™s swinging melody swells into action. The best part is when you close in on that absolutely slamming breakdown â€“ the crescendo where your choristers rise up like an army of heavenly warriors behind you. Nothing can stop you now, you have risen.

Henrietta Taylor

Contributing writer

2. â€˜My Wayâ€™ by Frank Sinatra

No, I canâ€™t hit the notes... but who can? Big Frankâ€™s â€˜My Wayâ€™ is a tectonic but tender reflection on his life, loves and career. And itâ€™s perfect for belting out in horrifically sweaty, spittle-spurting fashion. If you donâ€™t want to embarrass yourself too much, the trick is to start out singing the opening notes and verses as low as possible. Then, by the time you get around to throwing out those final, glorious choruses, youâ€™re not left squeaking. Regrets... Iâ€™ve had a few.

Ed Cunningham

News Editor, Time Out UK and Time Out London

Advertising

3. â€˜Juiceâ€™ by Lizzo

Easy on the vocal cords but heavy on the self-love, Lizzoâ€™s â€˜Juiceâ€™ is a proper girlâ€™s night anthem. With its funk-pop feel and infectiously self-assured lyrics like â€˜baby, Iâ€™m the whole damn mealâ€™ and â€˜Iâ€™m like Chardonnay, get better over timeâ€™ if you start off a little shy on the mic, this song will soon get the confidence oozing out of you. As the queen of self-empowerment, youâ€™d be committing a personal offence against Lizzo if you donâ€™t belt â€˜Juiceâ€™ out with 11/10 effort.

4. â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ by Prince

Now that our patron saint of frilly-bloused, pan-erotic, disco-rock-sex-funk has sadly shuffled off this mortal coil, his signature slow jam can serve as much as tribute as a â€œlet's-slow-things-downâ€ showpiece in your karaoke rep. If it's not too lofty to put that pressure on what isâ€”let's face itâ€”a mostly frivolous activity, a karaoke run at â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ might even lift some spirits. Sung in a gracious middle key (Eb, as the preview screen helpfully reminds you) rather than Prince's frequent falsetto squeal, it should allow you to bare your soul without any embarrassing high-register mishaps.

Advertising

5. â€˜Since U Been Goneâ€™ by Kelly Clarkson

The simple chord progression and the restrained vocals in the beginning of Clarksonâ€™s 2004 hit make for one of the greatest buildups to a powerhouse chorus is pop music. Sing this in front of a room full of strangers and the whole lot will be scream-belting, â€˜But since youâ€™ve been gone, I can breathe for the first time!â€™ Donâ€™t worry thoughâ€”youâ€™ll likely get your chance to shine solo again come the verses.

6. â€˜I Want It That Wayâ€™ by the Backstreet Boys

Lurking behind the shimmery Nordic production of this megahit is a great soul ballad. The lyrics are famously nonsensical, owing to Swedish producer and songwriter Max Martin's tenuous grasp of English, but poetry's beside the point when you've got one of pop music's catchiest choruses. Kevin Richardsonâ€”BSB's â€˜The Old Oneâ€™ â€”perceptively nailed the song's appeal with his assessment: "There are a lot of songs out there that don't make sense, but make you feel good when you sing along to them, and that's one of them." Couldn't think of a better karaoke endorsement than that.

Advertising

7. â€™I Wanna Dance With Somebodyâ€™ by Whitney Houston

Whitneyâ€™s 1987 smash remains an invigorating blast of lovelorn pop glory, her powerful, agile voice soaring effortlessly over spritely synths and funk-syncopated guitar. The whole thing makes the achingly lonely search for a dance floor soulmate sound like the best Friday night ever. Of course, nobodyâ€™s alone at karaoke. Especially if you nail that third-act key change.

8. â€˜I Will Surviveâ€™ by Gloria Gaynor

Sometimes you need to get in front of a group of strangers and make it clear that, no matter what challenges or misfortune the world throws in your path, youâ€™re going to persevere. In those situations, you canâ€™t go wrong with disco diva Gloria Gaynorâ€™s iconic breakup anthem, which brought empowerment to the dance floor when the track debuted in 1978. Settle for â€™90s alt-rockers Cakeâ€™s cover of this tune if you must, but Gaynorâ€™s original version is infinitely more groovy.

Advertising

9. â€˜Love Shackâ€™ by the B-52s

The B-52sâ€™ 1989 signature hit â€“ sorry, â€˜Rock Lobsterâ€™ â€“ works fabulously at karaoke because itâ€™s kind of an audience participation number. After you deliver Cindy Wilsonâ€™s classic â€˜your what?â€™ line, the entire room can yell back: â€˜Tin roof... rusted!â€™ But really, â€˜Love Shackâ€™ is so much fun to sing and listen to that the whole shack will be shimmying long before then.

10. â€˜Donâ€™t Stop Believinâ€™â€™ by Journey

At this point, saying that this fist-pumping, heart-swelling arena rock anthem is a good karaoke jam is like pointing out that â€˜Happy Birthdayâ€™ is an ideal song to sing on someoneâ€™s birthday. Itâ€™s so obvious - and overdone - itâ€™s probably not even worth including on a list like this, lest it inspire yet another full-bar singalong for the 9,425,567th time. But thatâ€™s the whole point: karaoke is a communal experience, and no matter how hard your eyes may roll whenever you hear that melodramatic keyboard intro, by the time your faux Steve Perry reaches the part about â€˜strangers waitin' up and down the boulevardâ€™, youâ€™ll have fully given in, along with everyone else in the pub. Really, itâ€™s the song karaoke was made for. Believe that.

Advertising

11. â€˜Stand by Meâ€™ by Ben E. King

No karaoke outing is complete without a teary moment, and here's yours, courtesy of the 1961 classic â€˜Stand by Meâ€™ which has been covered more than 400 times (no, we're not including your karaoke version in that count). Written by Ben E. King with song gods Leiber and Stoller, the song has its roots in a gospel standard called â€˜Lord Stand by Meâ€™ and certainly its reach goes beyond regular pop romanceâ€”as evidenced by its inclusion in the 1986 right of passage movie Stand by Me. Watch, listen, sing, cryâ€”oh, and enjoy.

12. â€˜Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)â€™ by Eurythmics

Who are we to disagree with the power of one of Annie Lennoxâ€™s most prominent new wave anthems, written with musical partner Dave Stewart in the wake of the demise of their former band, The Tourists. Thereâ€™s a decent chance that you already know the repetitive lyrics to this â€™80s bop built around a pair of intersecting synthesizer riffs, so hold your head up and sing this karaoke song loud.

Advertising

13. â€˜Born to Runâ€™ by Bruce Springsteen

Thereâ€™s something about an Americana ode to blue-collar youth that makes for a surefire karaoke classic, and no one knows this better than the Boss. Released in 1975, this song was his first charting single, the one that laid the foundation for decades of battered blue jeans and working-class anthems. And all these years later, a well delivered â€˜Tramps like us / Baby we were born to runâ€™ will still slay a crowd.

14. â€˜Rehabâ€™ by Amy Winehouse

Right off the bat, you get the chorus: â€˜They tried to make me go to rehab!â€™ Itâ€™s fantastic when pop songs do that, no dillydallying, no buildup. The audience will know immediately what you are singing, and they will respond, â€˜No, no, no!â€™ Of course, you must sing this karaoke song completely blitzed out of your mind. Sobriety is to this tune what satanists are to gospel. If you don't fall off the stage by that final â€˜I wonâ€™t go,â€™ spilling into a cocktail table, ending the night in stains, you did it wrong.

Advertising

15. â€˜Killing Me Softlyâ€™ by The Fugees

A hip-hop-inflected cover of Roberta Flackâ€™s interpretation of a ballad by â€™70s singer-songwriter Lori Lieberman (inspired by her experience at concert headlined by â€˜American Pikeâ€™ troubadour Don McLean), this hit by the Fugees works best as a karaoke song if youâ€™ve got a whole lot of confidence or a killer set of pipes. Backed only by a sparse drum beat, youâ€™ll be able to put your own spin on Lauryn Hillâ€™s silky vocal melodiesâ€” and donâ€™t be afraid to designate a hype man to take care of the â€˜one time, two timeâ€™ asides or to help belt out the chorus.

16. â€˜Bohemian Rhapsodyâ€™ by Queen

The high pomp of opera and the gutter circumstance of rock & roll tangle memorably in Queenâ€™s classic 1975 art-rock epic. No one can sing like Freddie Mercury, of course, but the motley nature of the songâ€”which segues from plaintive ballad and quasiclassical choral harmonies to guitar-driven rebel yellâ€”means that pretty much anything goes, from melodramatic group sing-along (â€˜Bismillah! No, we will not let you go!â€™ â€˜Let him go!â€™) to Wayneâ€™s Worldâ€“style head-thrashing.

Advertising

17. â€˜These Boots are Made for Walkinâ€™â€™ by Nancy Sinatra

Sassy ladies (and hey, gents too), your moment has arrived! This sultry, defiant â€™60s pop staple is among the crowning jewels of Sinatra's glittering collaborations with songwriter Lee Hazlewood and works best in performance when its singer is backed up by a troupe of go-go dancers. Bribe your friends.

18. â€˜Faithâ€™ by George Michael

As soon as this songâ€™s iconic, Bo Diddley-inspired riff kicks in, youâ€™ll have the karaoke crowd in the palm of your hands. Channelling the soulful vocal style of the late, great George Michael isnâ€™t going to be easy, so make sure you throw everything into the climactic â€˜baby!â€™. And if you want to shake your ass like GM in the video, hey, who is anyone to judge?

Advertising

19. â€˜Say It Ainâ€™t Soâ€™ by Weezer

Okay, so this song made its name on its monster guitar riff. But with its esoteric, affecting lyrics and Rivers Cuomoâ€™s bellowed â€˜say it ainâ€™t so, whoa, whoa,â€™ itâ€™s simply made to be one of the best karaoke songs. The only problem youâ€™ll have is figuring out where to stash the mike as you furiously air-guitar.

20. â€˜Ice, Ice Babyâ€™ by Vanilla Ice

Every human should be able to recite at least one couplet from this 1990 global smash, do so without shame. Yes, the song is so stupid in so many ways, but it's also a stone-cold specimen of pristine pop. Theres that perfect bassline, swiped from â€˜Under Pressureâ€™ by Queen and David Bowie, Iceâ€™s ludicrous braggadocio (â€˜Quick to the point to the point no fakinâ€™ / Cookinâ€™ MCs like a pound of baconâ€™) and, of course, that dance routine with those pants. Word to your mother.

Advertising

21. â€˜Be My Babyâ€™ by the Ronettes

Nearly every list of the best songs ever recorded has â€˜Be My Babyâ€™ somewhere near the top, and deservedly so. Ronnie Spector was rock & rollâ€™s first bad girl, so pay your respects by putting this gem in the karaoke song queue. Phil Spectorâ€™s studio magic made the song a pop touchstone, but Ronnieâ€™s spunky charm makes it a karaoke classic.

22. â€˜(You Gotta) Fight For Your Right (to Party)â€™ by Beastie Boys

There are few requirements involved in performing the Beastie Boysâ€™ brazen ode to youthful rebellion. You must be awake. You must be able to read. The barrier to entry is low for this karaoke song, making it one of your easiest and best options for some sophomoric fun. Itâ€™s also highly recommended to have a gaggle of friends on stage all yelling with you into one microphone. But really, in the spirit of the song, there are no rules. If someone tries to tell you otherwise, throw a pie in their face.

Advertising

23. â€˜(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Womanâ€™ by Aretha Franklin

Just the sound of those opening piano chords is enough to send anyone with ears into a swoon, such is the singular beauty of this 1967 Goffin and King classic. The question is, do you have the pipesâ€”or the chutzpahâ€”to take it on? Arethaâ€™s spine-tinglingly sung point here is that her man makes her feel like a red-blooded, musky, perfect-as-she-is woman, and she wants to bust open her heart to tell you this glorious truth. Sing it like a queen, or not at all.

24. â€˜Regulateâ€™ by Warren G featuring Nate Dogg

For a certain generation of rap fans - and even non-fans who just watched a lot of MTV back in the â€˜90s and absorbed it subconsciously - the words to this West Coast gangsta classic live in the same part of the brain that also contains the lyrics to the Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme, Smash Mouthâ€™s â€˜All Starâ€™ and several childhood nursery rhymes. That is to say, most everyone can recite every single line from memory, from the snippet of Young Guns dialogue at the beginning to the â€˜chordsâ€¦stringsâ€¦we bringsâ€¦melodyâ€™ part at the end. Itâ€™s also one of the best karaoke duets, although youâ€™ll certainly have to roshambo for the Nate Dogg role.

Advertising

25. â€˜Wake Me Up Before You Go Goâ€™ by Wham!

This Motown-inspired pop banger has more energy than a labrador puppy. That makes it a guaranteed karaoke crowd-pleaser even if music snobs might try to tell you itâ€™s â€˜a bit cheesyâ€™. Theyâ€™re wrong, obviously, and do not let his put you off. If youâ€™re not much of a singer, just play Andrew to your singing partnerâ€™s George and deliver a Grammy-winning performance on air tambourine.

26. â€˜Islands in the Streamâ€™ by Kenny Rogers and Dolly Parton

Written by the Bee Gees, this chart-topping 1983 duet has become a karaoke staple. Even if your singing voice lacks even a trace of country grit, itâ€™s a song you canâ€™t really go wrong with, not least because everyone in the room will be singing along by the time you reach the chorus. Best performed in a cowboy hat with a hint of a line-dancing shuffle.

Advertising

27. â€˜Tears of a Clownâ€™ by Smokey Robinson and the Miracles

When that opening calliope riff hits, everyone in the bar will know youâ€™ve just cued up Smokeyâ€™s timeless ode to weepy bedroom solitude. To sell it, youâ€™ll need to summon the gods of skyscraper-topping Motown vocals (the original was recorded at the famed labelâ€™s studio A) so why not take a tip from the pros. Legendary Apollo Theater performers like Robinson would rub a lucky tree stump before heading out on the stage. Find the nearest arboreal equivalent (most likely some formica paneling) and go for it.

28. â€˜Crazyâ€™ by Patsy Cline

When everyone else is screaming out pop hits like cans of spray cheese gone amok, class up the joint with Patsy Clineâ€™s mournful country classic, written for her by Willie Nelson in 1961. The simple melody doesnâ€™t require vocal pyrotechnics, so this is good choice for less showy singers. And the slow, steady tempo gives you plenty of room to croon, back-phrase and otherwise make the song yours.

Advertising

29. â€˜Baby Got Backâ€™ by Sir Mix-A-Lot

Like the Nostrodamus of butts, Sir Mix-a-Lot foresaw a future in which weâ€™d all be as obsessed with ass as he is. Nicki Minaj sampled him heavily for â€˜Anacondaâ€™, J. Lo and Iggy Azalea gifted the world with a track simply titled â€˜Booty,â€™ and Kim Kardashian is a person who exists. No karaoke night is complete without a salute to the song that started it all.

30. â€˜Youâ€™ve Lost That Lovinâ€™ Feelingâ€™ by the Righteous Brothers

When it comes to musical moments in Top Gun, the greatest is undeniably Kenny Loggins's â€˜Playing with the Boysâ€™ set against the homoerotic gloss of a beach volleyball game, but Cruise and Goose crooning the Righteous Brothers in a bar is probably more remembered. That scene is the genesis for every impulse to dial up this doo-wop in a karaoke parlour, because a 1986 fighter-jet movie remains more relevant than blue-eyed balladry produced by Phil Spector half a century ago. It's cheesy and effective, like Cruise himself. But heed the warning of Goose: â€˜She's lost that loving feeling? I hate it when she does that.â€™

Advertising

31. â€˜Drunk in Loveâ€™ by Jay-Z and Beyonce

Sure, itâ€™s a duet, but really you know who's wearing the pants (or at least, tiny underpants) here: This is YoncÃ©'s joint, from its trap beats and shuddering subterranean bassline to the singer's febrile, sometimes cartoonish vocals (â€˜graininâ€™ on that woodâ€™ ). Select this song for karaoke, and be prepared to go the distance with its delivery: not recommended for work parties.

32. â€˜Pour Some Sugar on Meâ€™ by Def Leppard

â€˜Gunter glieben glauten globen!â€™ Huh? Thatâ€™s Rock of Ages, you say? Look, all Def Leppard smashes are the same, sex-craved kaiju with kick drums like empty cargo ships and blue balls falsetto, glossed up in producer Mutt Langeâ€™s Wall of Hairspray sound. You can gunter glieben glauten globen over any damn one you please. As you stand there onstage, looking around the bar for packets of sugar to dump on your head for dramatic effect, the heretofore unrealized inanity of the lyrics really sinks in. The song rhymes â€˜trampâ€™ with â€˜video vampâ€™. Whoâ€™s pouring sugar on whom, and what exactly is a â€˜radar phoneâ€™? Shut off your brain and air guitar.

Advertising

33. â€˜Africaâ€™ by Toto

Letâ€™s face it: Thereâ€™s no way you can hit those high notes on the chorus, and no oneâ€”and we mean no oneâ€”has any idea what vocalist David Paich is carrying on about. But man, is that fake-tribal verse smooth, and man, is that chorus melody sweet. This is one of those karaoke songs that gets the whole room singing along or at the very least trying its best.

34. â€˜A Little Respectâ€™ by Erasure

This synth-pop classic is nothing short of transcendent: an LGBTQ+ anthem, absolutely, but also a banger covered by â€˜Teenage Dirtbagâ€™ band Wheatus and memorably used in â€˜Scrubsâ€™. Few of us can hit Andy Bellâ€™s skyscraping notes; few of us can resist trying to do so anyway. And yes, you do deserve â€˜A Little Respectâ€™ just for stepping up to the mike.

Advertising

35. â€˜Party in the U.S.A.â€™ by Miley Cyrus

Poke fun at her dorky Hannah Montana days or the infamous bedazzled weed leotard all you likeâ€”thereâ€™s no denying that Miley Cyrus has given the world some bonafide karaoke classics (or Bangerz, if you will). Before you break into one of her most memorable tracks, youâ€™ll probably want to wait until everyone at the bar is at least a couple drinks in, just to ensure that everyone is movinâ€™ their hips and shakinâ€™ their heads (like, yeah) when you all start belting out the chorus.

36. â€˜Sweet Child oâ€™ Mineâ€™ by Guns Nâ€™ Roses

â€˜Sweet Child oâ€™ Mine,â€™ this iconic bandâ€™s only U.S. No. 1 single, is a 10-point routine for Axl Rose imitators. It starts with your nuts in a bunch, full-on banshee Axl, before letting you really chew into his Brit imitation and serious busker mode on â€˜Where do we go now?â€™ bridge, which of course climaxes into a glass-shattering falsetto shriek. Place that order for lemon and honey tea beforehand.

Advertising

37. â€˜Heart of Glassâ€™ by Blondie

If youâ€™re pretty confident in your upper register, this shimmering disco classic is an excellent choice at karaoke. If youâ€™re, well, a little less steady on those high notes, you can still make â€˜Heart of Glassâ€™ work for you. Just channel Debbie Harryâ€™s quintessential NYC cool as best as you can before really letting rip on a bridge that no one can mess up: â€˜Da-da-da, da-dum-da-dum-da, da-dum-da-da-da...â€™

38. â€˜The Boy is Mineâ€™ by Brandy and Monica

This super slinky 1998 number was guaranteed to be a hit for its singersâ€”pitched as an â€˜answer songâ€™ to MJ and Paul McCartneyâ€™s 1982 duet â€˜The Girl Is Mineâ€™, it played off the supposed rivalry between the two female R&B stars. But thatâ€™s beside the point when you hear the song, which still sounds crisper and cooler than an icicle at a club in an iglooâ€”and guarantees any karaoke singer the opportunity to channel his or her belligerent feelings into the musical expression of eyebrows raised and arms folded: â€˜I'm sorry that you seem to be confused.â€™ Snap.

Advertising

39. â€˜Hold Onâ€™ by Wilson Phillips

Did you know that in 1990, â€˜Hold Onâ€™ bumped Madonnaâ€™s â€˜Vogueâ€™ off the top spot of the Billboard charts? Did you know that Wilson Phillips' debut album sold more than 10 million copies? Did you know that â€˜Hold Onâ€™ is actually a perfect, if weirdly nauseating, karaoke song? Of course you did! And very likely you loved every minute of the trioâ€™s cameo in the 2011 movie Bridesmaids, too. Time to re-create the magic.

40. â€˜Someone Like Youâ€™ by Adele

Still pining for your ex when friends drag you to karaoke night? Thereâ€™s only one song for you. Save it for when youâ€™re four drinks in and ready to make the crowd deeply uncomfortable. Donâ€™t worry if you donâ€™t have Adeleâ€™s vocal chopsâ€”the tears streaming down your face will distract everyone from the high notes youâ€™re mangling.

Advertising

41. â€˜Drop It Like Itâ€™s Hotâ€™ by Snoop Dogg

Can you twerk? Are you willing to try? If you answered no, please pass the mike to someone bolder or more inebriated. Covering Snoopâ€™s ode to glutes is as much an embarrassing dance routine as a karaoke number: â€˜Get low.â€™ â€˜Scrub the ground.â€™ Pharrellâ€™s beat, which sounds like bacon fat on a skillet and pulling lollipops out of a mouth, is equally lascivious. Best not to try this one out at the wedding party in front of the grand-in-laws. But among your friends? You're going home lucky. Or with wet pants.

42. â€˜Hey Yaâ€™ by Outkast

If singing isnâ€™t your strongest suitâ€”but youâ€™re fantastic at jumping around and getting everybody pumpedâ€”then fire up this early aughts favorite. Better plan ahead though if you want to match the tune in your best AndrÃ© â€˜Ice Coldâ€™ 3000 green get-up.

Advertising

43. â€˜Creepâ€™ by Radiohead

Thereâ€™s a cheap gimmick for scoring a pop hit: cursing in the chorus. The radio stations may have to bleep out the words, but we love belting out those f-bombs in cars and bars. It worked wonders for Cee Loâ€™s â€˜Fuck Youâ€™ and Gwen Stefaniâ€™s â€˜Hollaback Girl.â€™ Likewise, would Radiohead ever have been able to become Radiohead without that angsty refrain of â€˜youâ€™re so fucking specialâ€™ in 1994? Probably not. However, Jonny Greenwoodâ€™s radical guitar interjectionâ€”chunk-unk!â€”turned the power chord into expletive and proved these guys were smarter than the text.

44. â€˜Say My Nameâ€™ Destinyâ€™s Child

For an R&B song boasting amazing female vocalists (including, you know, BeyoncÃ©), â€˜Say My Nameâ€™ doesnâ€™t require all that big a singing range. What it does need, however, is some pretty fast talking. To impress the rest of the bar, make sure you got the lyrics on lockâ€”or maybe the support of your personal Kelly Rowland, Letoya Luckett and LaTavia Robertson.

Advertising

45. â€˜(I Canâ€™t Get No) Satisfactionâ€™ by the Rolling Stones

That riff, a cross between a sitar and a revving dirt bike, is the most recognizable thing about the song. For such a ubiquitous hit, the lyrics continually surprise beyond the titular chorus. So much so that when Cat Power covered the tune in 2000, slicing off the refrain, it was a strange new poem about the anxiety of commercials and subliminal advertising. This from the first rock band to develop a brand logo, a pair of juicy red lips.
